conclusion: A conductor of length L that moves with speed v perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field B develops an emf E = B L v.
In the present geometry the length across which the emf is measured is the inside diameter d of the pipe, so L = d.

premise: E = B L v and L = d
conclusion: The (average) speed of the liquid v equals v = E /( B d ).
The volume flow rate Q is the product of this speed and the pipe’s cross-sectional area A.
The pipe’s cross-sectional area A is A = π d² /4.

premise: Q = A v and v = E /( B d ) and A = π d² /4

conclusion: Flow rate of the conductive liquid: Q = (π d E) / (4 B).
